Search for:
1. Can ppro.app.enableQE() be called from UXP?
2. Is the global 'qe' object available in UXP context?
3. Has anyone successfully used QE DOM from a UXP plugin?
4. Adobe forum discussions about QE + UXP
5. GitHub repos that attempt QE access from UXP
6. Will QE DOM continue to exist after September 2026?
7. Is QE DOM part of the deprecated ExtendScript or separate?
8. Any Adobe statements about QE DOM's future
9. Alternative ways to access QE functionality
10. Any bridges or workarounds to call QE from UXP

Search Adobe forums, GitHub, Stack Overflow, Reddit, and developer blogs. We need definitive answers about QE DOM's availability in UXP and its future.

This is research only - provide all findings with sources.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding Adobe Premiere Pro's transition from ExtendScript to UXP and the deprecation timeline:

## Premiere Pro ExtendScript and UXP Transition

### Timeline and Deprecation

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

### UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform)

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### Key Differences Between ExtendScript and UXP

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### QE DOM Status

There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. However, the QE DOM will remain 100% unsupported and not at all recommended.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin is described as the right starting point for any future integrations, showing how to clone and remove track items.

### Migration Recommendations

UXP is described as "the future" - all CEP panels will have to be migrated to UXP at some point. Testing UXP and providing feedback now will ensure that when CEP starts getting phased out, developers aren't stuck waiting on bug fixes or new features from Adobe to complete migrations.

Here are the search results from the Adobe Community forums regarding Premiere Pro, QE DOM, and UXP plugins:

## Key Findings

### QE DOM Status
"There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. Of course, the QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."(no content)The QE DOM API appears incomplete - for example, it doesn't seem possible to set the source-target patches, or to do things like control the zoom or view of the timeline.(no content)There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.

### UXP Plugin Development
The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin is "the right starting point for any future integrations" and shows how to clone and remove track items.(no content)The current plan is to officially release UXP extensibility, approaching 1:1 parity, this calendar year (2025); perhaps even this summer. Placing trackItems into sequences has been in UXP for months, and Adobe is working on .mogrt APIs.(no content)Adobe's first goal is parity with what ExtendScript could already do. Applying effects works, and UXP plugins can make Undo groupings, instead of introducing a new Undo item with each API call.

### CEP to UXP Transition
CEP extensions are "100% definitely still supported." The plan is to continue to support them for a calendar year beyond the release of UXP extensibility in non-beta PPro builds.

### Resources
Sample UXP plugins are available at https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples/tree/main, documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/, and there's a PPro UXP Dev Forum at https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105

Based on the search results, I found several relevant GitHub repositories related to Premiere Pro UXP, QE, and the `enableQE` function. Here's a summary of the findings:

## Key Results for "Premiere Pro UXP QE enableQE"

### QE (Quality Engineering) API Usage

The Adobe CEP Samples repository shows how `app.enableQE()` is used in ExtendScript to enable the QE DOM, which then allows access to functions like `qe.project.newSequence()` and source player controls like `qe.source.player.startScrubbing()`, `qe.source.player.scrubTo()`, and `qe.source.player.endScrubbing()`.(no content)The PremiereRemote project demonstrates using `app.enableQE()` in a function like: 
```javascript
function lockVideoLayer(layerNumber) { 
  app.enableQE(); 
  var activeSequence = qe.project.getActiveSequence(); 
  var someTrack = activeSequence.getVideoTrackAt(layerNumber); 
  someTrack.setLock(true); 
}
```

### About the QE API

The QE (Quality Engineering) API is used by Adobe to run automated tests for development purposes. Although it is not officially supported by Adobe, it is usable alongside the official API. The pymiere library offers an entry point to QE using `pymiere.objects.qe`.(no content)Note that QE is not fail-proof and you may crash Premiere while exploring it. Also, some of the methods seem to not be working or proper arguments are unknown.

### UXP in Premiere Pro

The AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples repository explains how to develop UXP plugins within Premiere Pro. As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.(no content)UXP scripting in Premiere Pro is experimental and limited. Some features (like timeline and sequence editing) may not be available yet. For full automation, use the CEP (legacy) panel.

### Related Resources

- **GitHub - amirul181/Adobe-Premiere-Pro-Quality-Engineering-QE-Unofficial-Documentation**: This repository provides unofficial documentation for Adobe Premiere Pro's Quality Engineering (QE) API.

- **GitHub - hyperbrew/bolt-uxp**: A lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe UXP Plugins in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP plugins and the `enableQE`/QE object access:

## UXP in Premiere Pro - Current Status

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6.(no content)UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a constantly growing set of applications, including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.

## QE Object Access

The `app.enableQE()` function enables Premiere Pro's QE DOM and returns true if QE DOM was enabled.

However, there are important considerations:

There have been "zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled." However, "the QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."(no content)Community feedback notes that "app.enableQE() is not easy and open and absolutely not well documented."

## Known Issues with QE DOM

Some developers have reported issues with QE functions like `moveToTrack()`: "in current Premiere Pro builds (2023–2025), this function appears to exist in the QE object model but is not operational."(no content)There is currently "no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks" and "the function in QE appears to be stubbed or deprecated without a documented replacement."

## Migration from ExtendScript to UXP

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to UXP-based extensibility. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported and planned to remain so through September 2026.(no content)Adobe recommends the 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin as "the right starting point for any future integrations," which shows how to clone and remove track items.

## Accessing the Premiere API via UXP

To access the Premiere DOM via UXP, the documentation states that a specific line allows you access, from which "you can open documents, modify them, run menu items, and more."

## Resources

- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- Adobe has updated sample code to help developers get started, and "The Sample SDK provides practical examples of how to interact with the Premiere API using UXP."

Based on my search, here's what I found regarding `app.enableQE()` in UXP for Premiere Pro:

`app.enableQE()` is not easy and open and absolutely not well documented. This has been a known issue within the Adobe community.

According to an Adobe Employee (Bruce Bullis) responding to this concern:

It's unlikely that Adobe will be making any large changes to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API; their scripting-related efforts are focused on exposing those APIs for use from within UXP "plug-ins" (which are actually extensions).

At the time of that discussion (December 2020), UXP plug-ins didn't yet exist in Premiere Pro, though they were available in Adobe XD and Photoshop. Adobe had announced no dates for Premiere Pro UXP support but was working on it.(no content)Adobe suggested that developers should continue using Premiere Pro's ExtendScript (.jsx) APIs until a replacement becomes available. While they understood the desire for more complete API control around inserting and modifying effects, that work was unlikely to be done in ExtendScript and would instead hopefully be part of efforts to re-expose APIs for use from UXP plug-ins.

**Key takeaways:**
- The `app.enableQE()` function is part of the "Quality Engineering" (QE) DOM in Premiere Pro, which provides additional functionality not available in the standard scripting API
- This QE API is largely undocumented and has been difficult to work with
- Adobe's focus has shifted toward UXP for future scripting capabilities in Premiere Pro
- If you're trying to use `app.enableQE()` in a UXP context and it's not working, it may be because QE functionality hasn't been fully ported to UXP yet

## Key Findings

### QE DOM Status
"No additional work is planned on the unsupported, undocumented PPro ExtendScript QE DOM."(no content)"There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. Of course, the QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."

### What is the QE DOM?
"Short for Quality Engineering. The QE DOM was created for internal automation and testing use. Still, as you noted, it provides loads of interesting and useful functions. You also mentioned the QE DOM's Achilles heel: its project model refreshing is unreliable. Thus, the QE DOM remains officially unsupported, and not recommended."

### ExtendScript Deprecation
"The ExtendScript language, which was used for legacy scripts and CEP extensions, has been deprecated. Meanwhile, Photoshop engineers took the opportunity to rebuild the Photoshop Document Object Model (DOM) from scratch."(no content)"The Extendscript Toolkit has been deprecated in favour of The VS Code Debugger! This information is preserved here for legacy reference, but the Extendscript Toolkit is no longer being actively maintained or supported, and will no longer work on 64-bit-only versions of MacOS."

### New Alternative: UXP
"The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin, the right starting point for any future integrations, shows how to clone and remove track items."(no content)"UXP provides different methods for accessing the Photoshop DOM. See the Photoshop UXP API reference for more information. At present, the entire DOM is not yet supported, but more access is being added with every Photoshop release. As a workaround until all the significant Photoshop features are accessible via UXP, you can use a feature called batchPlay."

### Known Issues with QE DOM
"Glad it's worked fine for you; you've been lucky. The QE DOM has some issues updating itself, in response to user interaction."(no content)"The function in QE appears to be stubbed or deprecated without a documented replacement."

In summary, Adobe's QE DOM is an unofficial, unsupported API that was created for internal testing purposes. While ExtendScript itself has been deprecated in favor of UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform), the QE DOM specifically remains available but with no planned updates or official support. Developers are encouraged to migrate to UXP for future integrations.

content.content:
# QE DOM and UXP Information from Adobe Community

## QE DOM Status

According to Bruce Bullis (Adobe Employee), the QE DOM remains **unchanged and unsupported**:

> "there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. Of course, the QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported"

## UXP as Recommended Path

Adobe's official guidance directs developers toward UXP instead. The `premiere_api` UXP example plugin demonstrates how to manipulate timeline items through clone and remove operations rather than direct track movement.

## QE Accessibility from UXP

The documentation indicates **no direct QE DOM access from UXP plugins**. UXP uses the documented Premiere Pro API, which provides different capabilities than the unsupported QE layer.

## Key Limitation

There is **no current programmatic method** (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) to move existing clips vertically between tracks while preserving timing—a critical gap for automation workflows.

## Future Direction

No roadmap information suggests QE DOM will receive updates or become officially supported. Adobe's investment appears focused on UXP as the forward-compatible scripting solution.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP bridge ExtendScript QE workaround calls:

## Current State of UXP and ExtendScript in Premiere Pro

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

## UXP API Design for Transition from ExtendScript

In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

## QE (Quality Engineering) Library Workaround in ExtendScript

For functionality not directly available in the standard ExtendScript API, there's a workaround using the QE library. Users have discovered that calling methods like the RAZOR method requires enabling the QE library first. The workaround involves:

Sample working code involves enabling the Quality Engineering library with `app.enableQE()`, then getting the active QE sequence with `qe.project.getActiveSequence()`, and using QE's razor method that can be called on a sequence object.

## CEP Extensions Bridge Architecture

CEP Extensions are comprised of a JavaScript/HTML/CSS frontend built on Node.js + Chromium (similar to NW.js) and an ExtendScript backend for interacting with the host application. UXP Plugins are also JavaScript/HTML/CSS based but built on Adobe's own unique stack which makes them far less resource heavy. Instead of a JavaScript frontend and ExtendScript backend like CEP, UXP has one unified environment for frontend code and host API calls, minimizing friction back and forth.

## Current Recommendations

No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.(no content)Adobe's first goal with UXP is parity with what ExtendScript could already do. Applying effects now works, and UXP plugins can make Undo groupings instead of introducing a new Undo item with each API call.(no content)For workarounds involving global keypresses, developers have created separate programs that run in the background as global keyboard hooks with websocket servers, where the server can talk to the extension JavaScript which can in turn call the ExtendScript.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about the "qe" object and UXP in Premiere Pro:

## QE Object in Premiere Pro

The QE DOM (Quality Engineering DOM) can be enabled in Premiere Pro through `app.enableQE()`, which returns true if the QE DOM was successfully enabled.

However, there's an important distinction between the legacy ExtendScript/CEP approach and the new UXP platform:

### Current Status (2025)

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6. This release represents a major step forward in modernizing the extensibility ecosystem.

### QE DOM Limitations

The API is not complete even when you dig into the QE DOM. For example, it doesn't seem possible to set the source-target patches, or to do things like control the zoom or view of the timeline.

### UXP Global Access

In UXP for Premiere Pro, global access works differently than in ExtendScript:

Global APIs are available immediately without any import. Module-based APIs require importing with `require()`.(no content)To access the Premiere DOM via UXP, you need a specific require line. From there, you can open documents, modify them, run menu items, and more.(no content)In the ExtendScript approach, the single global object is always available by its name, `app`.

**Note:** The QE object specifically appears to be part of the legacy ExtendScript/CEP API rather than the new UXP API. The UXP API is still evolving, and both UXP and Premiere APIs are actively evolving, with new capabilities added in each release.

Based on my search, here's what I found about calling ExtendScript JSX from UXP plugins in Premiere Pro:

## Key Findings

### Current State of Premiere Pro Extensibility (2024-2025)

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)On Dec 5th, 2024, Adobe opened their public beta for UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro. This moment has been long-awaited by Premiere plugin developers since UXP was originally announced by Adobe back in 2019.

### UXP vs ExtendScript Architecture

UXP Plugins are JavaScript/HTML/CSS based, built on Adobe's own unique stack which makes them far less resource heavy than CEP's Node.js + Chromium stack. Instead of a JavaScript frontend and ExtendScript backend like CEP, UXP has 1 unified environment for frontend code and host API calls, minimizing friction back and forth.

### Important Differences

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, blocking the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

### Migration Considerations

As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility. If you are starting new development, start in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which they will remove support for CEP extensibility.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled.

### Running JSX Scripts in Premiere Pro 2024

There is no way to execute a jsx script directly, unless you run it with VS Code and the ExtendScript Debugger.

### Resources

- UXP samples are available at: https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples and documentation at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/

**Important Note:** Unlike CEP where you could call ExtendScript from JavaScript via `evalScript()`, UXP in Premiere Pro does **not** provide a direct mechanism to call ExtendScript JSX code. UXP has its own native API that replaces the ExtendScript DOM, so you would need to migrate your ExtendScript code to use UXP's native APIs instead.

Here are the search results for QE DOM UXP in Premiere Pro:

## QE DOM and UXP in Premiere Pro

### Overview of UXP in Premiere Pro

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions programmatically.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported and planned to remain so through September 2026.(no content)UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a growing set of applications including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.

### Key Differences: UXP vs ExtendScript/QE DOM

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, blocking the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine with direct access to both the Premiere APIs and UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous CEP technology, where communication between the extension logic and host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface).

### QE DOM Status and Limitations

The API is not complete even when you dig into the QE DOM. For example, it doesn't seem possible to set the source-target patches, or to control the zoom or view of the timeline.(no content)There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. The QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported and not recommended.(no content)In current Premiere Pro builds (2023–2025), functions like `moveToTrack()` appear to exist in the QE object model but are not operational, returning errors like "not enough parameters" or "illegal parameter type."(no content)There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.

### Getting Started with UXP

Instructions for developing UXP plugins within Premiere Pro are available. As of August 2025, only Premiere Pro BETA builds support UXP plugins. Documentation is available at developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin is the right starting point for any future integrations, showing how to clone and remove track items.

### Forum Resources

For UXP-related questions, you can post in the UXP forum at forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105.

Note: The search didn't return results directly from forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com, but the above information from Adobe's official documentation and community forums should provide a comprehensive overview of QE DOM and UXP in Premiere Pro.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding Bruce Bullis's statements about QE DOM, Premiere Pro's future, and UXP:

## Key Statements from Bruce Bullis (Adobe Employee)

### QE DOM Status
Bruce Bullis stated that there have been "zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled." However, he emphasized that "the QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."

### UXP Future for Premiere Pro
As of June 2025, Bruce Bullis indicated that "The current plan is to officially release UXP extensibility, approaching 1:1 parity, this calendar year; perhaps even this summer."(no content)"Placing trackItems into sequences has been in UXP for months. We are working on .mogrt APIs right now; the next SDK pre-release will contain that work."

### Historical Context
Back in June 2021, Bullis wrote: "UXP extensibility is definitely in PPro's future, but not our present. We're working on re-exposing our API functionality in a way that it's accessible from UXP plug-ins, but are not yet ready to host third parties. Once PPro does have UXP hosting, we'll definitely make that fact broadly known."

### CEP Transition Timeline
Regarding the transition from CEP to UXP, Bullis stated: "Even once UXP is fully supported, Adobe will provide an overlapping period during which both mechanisms are supported; we can't make promises, but with the Flex --> CEP transition, that was about 1.75 years of overlap. We have no plans to decommission support for CEP, without first allowing for a significant overlap period."

### Current Status (as of November 2025)
"As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP; Unified Extensibility Platform." ExtendScript-based integrations "are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026."(no content)For future integrations, Bullis recommends: "The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin, the right starting point for any future integrations, shows how to clone and remove track items."

Based on my search, here's what I found about Premiere Pro QE DOM, ExtendScript, and UXP:

## Key Findings

### QE DOM in ExtendScript
The QE DOM is enabled through Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API. When you call `app.enableQE()`, it returns true if QE DOM was enabled.(no content)The QE API allows developers to undo specific actions by calling `qe.project.undo()`. This functionality is not part of the official API.(no content)An important feature missing from the official API is the ability to apply effects on a clip. The QE DOM offers this feature by calling `addVideoEffect()` on a QETrackItem.(no content)Officially, the QE DOM is not recommended, or supported.(no content)The QE DOM has some issues updating itself, in response to user interaction.

### ExtendScript vs UXP Status
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous. This means they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled.

### Exploring the QE API
To get an up to date list of methods available in the QE DOM you could call `qe.reflect.methods`. While doing this manually is a tedious task, there are tools like the ExtendScript Developer Tools that can automate the process and allow you to inspect the QE API.

### Working with CEP Extensions
While the JavaScript layer of CEP is up-to-date and flexible to use, unfortunately when it comes to communicating with the host application, ExtendScript is still needed. In order for CEP Extensions to get information or send commands to the host application, such as After Effects or Premiere Pro, they must call functions in the ExtendScript layer.(no content)The API doesn't appear complete even when you dig into the QE DOM. For example, it doesn't seem possible to set the source-target patches for instance, or to do things like control the zoom or view of the timeline.

The QE DOM remains an ExtendScript-only feature and is not available in UXP. If you need QE DOM functionality, you'll need to continue using ExtendScript through CEP panels until support ends in September 2026.

Based on my search results, here's what I found regarding Premiere Pro UXP and the "qe" (QE DOM) access issues:

## Key Findings

### QE DOM in Premiere Pro

The QE DOM is a feature that can be enabled in Premiere Pro. It "enables Premiere Pro's QE DOM" and "returns true if QE DOM was enabled."(no content)To use the QE DOM, you need to explicitly enable it - the documentation shows that it "enables Premiere Pro's QE DOM" and "returns true if QE DOM was enabled."

### UXP Transition Impact

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

### QE DOM Limitations

The API is not complete even when you dig into the QE DOM. For example, it doesn't seem possible to set the source-target patches, or to do things like control the zoom or view of the timeline.

### Workarounds and Context

For certain operations like `app.project.activeSequence.insertClip()`, it would work as long as there's an active sequence in an open project. Broadly, you'd need to work through the DOM to get to a specific item to manipulate, rather than issuing contextual commands.

If you're encountering "qe undefined" or "cannot access" errors, it's likely because:
1. The QE DOM needs to be explicitly enabled using `app.enableQE()` before accessing QE objects
2. With the transition to UXP, some legacy ExtendScript features may not be fully available or may require different approaches
3. The QE DOM has always had limitations in terms of available functionality

Would you like me to search for more specific solutions or workarounds for this issue?

content.content:
# Adobe Premiere Pro QE API: Comprehensive Overview

## Origin and Purpose

The QE API (Quality Engineering API) was originally built as an internal testing and automation tool for Adobe. According to the documentation, it "was built for internal testing and automation" but "is now available to all Premiere Pro Plugin developers."

## Current Status and Support

The API remains **officially unsupported** despite widespread use. The source explicitly states: "Officially, the QE API isn't supported, although it's extensively utilized to realize features that wouldn't be possible otherwise."

## Functionality

Key capabilities include:
- Undo operations via `qe.project.undo()`
- Retrieving available video effects through `qe.project.getVideoEffectList()`
- Applying effects to clips using `addVideoEffect()` on QETrackItem objects
- Project management functions like `newProject()` and `resetProject()`

## UXP Compatibility

**No information provided** in the source material regarding UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) support or compatibility.

## Deprecation and Future

The documentation contains **no statements about deprecation or planned discontinuation**, nor does it address the API's long-term future.

## Discovery and Inspection

Developers can explore available methods using reflection via `qe.reflect.methods`, with tools like the ExtendScript Developer Tools automating this introspection process to display current parameters and return types.

## Functionality

- Retrieving available video effects through `qe.project.getVideoEffectList()`
- Applying effects to clips using `addVideoEffect()` on QETrackItem objects
- Project management functions like `newProject()` and `resetProject()`

## UXP Compatibility

## Deprecation and Future

The documentation contains **no statements about deprecation or planned discontinuation**, nor does it address the API's long-term future.

## Discovery and Inspection

Developers can explore available methods using reflection via `qe.reflect.methods`, with tools like the ExtendScript Developer Tools automating this introspection process to display current parameters and return types.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Premiere Pro UXP, evalScript, and the ExtendScript bridge for calling JSX:

## Overview of the ExtendScript Bridge in Premiere Pro

### Current State of Extensibility

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

### Key Differences Between CEP/ExtendScript and UXP

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous. This means they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing.

### How evalScript Works (CEP Approach)

The CSInterface.evalScript function does not return the value. It is intended to be an asynchronous call. Instead, the callback you pass to evalScript is passed the value returned from the ExtendScript-side function.

**The process flow:**
1. Call to evalScript sends a request to process the code you send it. Your "outside" alert is triggered. The captured variable is still the empty string.
2. The ExtendScript (JSX) context is started and begins to process the request you sent it. The script you passed to ExtendScript (JSX) is processed, generating the return value you are interested in (coerces it to a string). The ExtendScript (JSX) context sends a request to process the string to the JS using the callback you specified. The panel (JS) context runs the callback that you provided to evalScript and only now will it have the chance to set the captured variable.

### Calling JSX Functions from JavaScript

You can call your function using `cs.evalScript('$.runScript.exportThis()')` or `cs.evalScript('exportThis()')`. How you call your function depends on how you have your JSX file formatted.(no content)We can only pass information to ExtendScript code as a "STRING". The way we do this is by providing a trigger in the HTML, for example, an input type="button" which on a click runs a JavaScript function.

### Passing Variables

Within the JS, there's a three-step process: 1) Declare a new CSInterface `var cs = new CSInterface;` (notice you must first provide a script link to include the CSInterface.js file).

### UXP vs CEP Decision

If UXP already supports what you're trying to do (or is close), Adobe recommends using UXP.(no content)It's important to note that CEP extensions are in the process of being replaced with UXP extensions, which no longer use the antiquated ExtendScript language, but instead use modern JavaScript on the frontend and backend.

### Common Issues

A common issue developers face is being unable to run ExtendScript in JSX file from the main.js file. Even with correct pathing and PlayerDebugMode set to 1 in Registry Editor, there is no proper error message—it just says EvalScript Error and is difficult to debug.

Based on my search results, I found relevant information about Premiere Pro UXP and its relationship with ExtendScript/evalScript. Here's what I found:

## Key Findings

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous. This means they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing.(no content)UXP Plugins are JavaScript/HTML/CSS based, however they are built on their own unique stack by Adobe which makes them far less resource heavy than CEP's Node.js + Chromium stack. Additionally, instead of a JavaScript frontend and ExtendScript backend like CEP, UXP has 1 unified environment for your frontend code and host API calls, minimizing friction back and forth.

This is a significant architectural change - CEP extensions are in the process of being replaced with UXP extensions, which no longer use the antiquated ExtendScript language, but instead use modern JavaScript on the frontend and backend.

## Current Status

As Adobe works toward providing UXP-based extensibility, they've stopped additional work on the ExtendScript API.(no content)Adobe's first goal for Premiere Pro UXP is parity with what ExtendScript could already do.(no content)UXP plugins can do things like applying effects, and can make Undo groupings instead of introducing a new Undo item with each API call.

## CEP vs UXP Architecture

In CEP panels, the `evalScript` function was used to call ExtendScript from the JavaScript context. The CSInterface.evalScript API is the method by which users are enabled to issue commands in the ExtendScript context from the panel (JavaScript) context.

However, UXP takes a fundamentally different approach - it doesn't use ExtendScript at all, which means **`evalScript` calls to ExtendScript are not part of the UXP architecture**. CEP and UXP each have their pros and cons, but the important thing to note is that UXP is replacing CEP, so tracking with UXP updates is very important for all Adobe 3rd party developers.

If you're migrating from CEP to UXP, you'll need to rewrite your ExtendScript code using UXP's native JavaScript APIs rather than using `evalScript` to call ExtendScript.

If you're migrating from CEP to UXP, you'll need to rewrite your ExtendScript code using UXP's native JavaScript APIs rather than using `evalScript` to call ExtendScript.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP plugin access to legacy APIs and workarounds in 2025:

## UXP Status in Premiere Pro (2025)

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP. ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

## Key Differences Between Legacy APIs and UXP

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition between the ExtendScript DOM and the UXP DOM, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.(no content)This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where the communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface) that passed messages back and forth between the two runtimes. With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment, and you just need to require() the appropriate modules to access the APIs you need.

## Legacy API (QE DOM) Status

There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. However, the QE DOM will remain 100% unsupported and not at all recommended.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

## API Parity and Timeline

The current plan is to officially release UXP extensibility approaching 1:1 parity with legacy APIs this calendar year (2025).(no content)Placing trackItems into sequences has been in UXP for months, and Adobe is working on .mogrt APIs with the next SDK pre-release containing that work.

## Workaround Approaches

For functionality gaps, the search results suggest:

1. The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items - this can serve as a workaround pattern for some operations.

2. If your plugin depends on APIs added in newer Premiere versions but the user is on an older version, you should target APIs common to both versions or implement fallback logic for older releases when possible.

3. There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks - some legacy functionality simply has no workaround currently.

## Resources

- Sample UXP plugins are available at https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples, with documentation at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ and a PPro UXP Dev Forum at https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105.

content.text:
Based on my exhaustive research, I can now provide you with comprehensive findings on QE DOM accessibility from UXP plugins in Premiere Pro.

---

# QE DOM Accessibility from UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro: Research Findings

## Executive Summary

**QE DOM is NOT accessible from UXP plugins.** The QE DOM is an ExtendScript-only feature that has no equivalent or bridge in the UXP architecture. There is no documented way to call `app.enableQE()` or access the `qe` global object from a UXP plugin.

---

## Detailed Findings

### 1. Can `app.enableQE()` be called from UXP?

**NO.** The `app.enableQE()` function is part of the ExtendScript API. UXP uses a completely different architecture with its own native JavaScript API. There is no `enableQE()` method in the UXP Premiere API.

- UXP has "1 unified environment for your frontend code and host API calls" - it does not use ExtendScript at all
- The UXP API is accessed via `require('premierepro')`, not through the legacy `app` global object

**Source:** [Hyper Brew - Premiere Pro UXP Beta](https://hyperbrew.co/blog/premiere-pro-uxp-beta/)

---

### 2. Is the global `qe` object available in UXP context?

**NO.** The `qe` global object only exists in the ExtendScript context. UXP does not expose this object.

- In ExtendScript: After calling `app.enableQE()`, the `qe` object becomes available
- In UXP: There is no equivalent mechanism; UXP uses its own API via `require('premierepro')`

**Source:** [Premiere Pro Scripting Guide](https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/)

---

### 3. Has anyone successfully used QE DOM from a UXP plugin?

**NO documented cases found.** My search across GitHub, Adobe forums, Stack Overflow, and developer blogs found no examples of QE DOM being accessed from UXP. All QE DOM usage examples are in ExtendScript/CEP contexts.

---

### 4. Adobe Forum Discussions about QE + UXP

Bruce Bullis (Adobe Employee) stated on Adobe forums:

> "There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. Of course, the QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."

> "The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin, the right starting point for any future integrations, shows how to clone and remove track items."

Key points from forum discussions:
- Adobe recommends UXP for all new development
- No mention of QE DOM being ported to UXP
- QE functionality gaps should be addressed through UXP API feature requests

**Sources:**
- [Adobe Community - Request for Timeline Editing API Support](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115)
- [Adobe Community - To UXP or not to UXP](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-pro-extensions-to-uxp-or-not-to-uxp/td-p/11326933)

---

### 5. GitHub Repos Attempting QE Access from UXP

**None found.** All repositories using QE DOM are ExtendScript/CEP-based:
- [Adobe-CEP/Samples/PProPanel](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx) - Uses QE in ExtendScript
- [AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples) - Pure UXP, no QE usage
- [amirul181/Adobe-Premiere-Pro-Quality-Engineering-QE-Unofficial-Documentation](https://github.com/amirul181/Adobe-Premiere-Pro-Quality-Engineering-QE-Unofficial-Documentation) - ExtendScript only

---

### 6. Will QE DOM Continue to Exist After September 2026?

**Uncertain, but likely YES (with ExtendScript support ending).**

- ExtendScript-based integrations are "still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026"
- After September 2026, CEP/ExtendScript support will be removed
- QE DOM is tied to ExtendScript, so **QE DOM access will likely cease when ExtendScript is removed**
- Adobe has stated: "No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled"

**Source:** [Adobe Developer - Premiere and UXP](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/introduction/)

---

### 7. Is QE DOM Part of ExtendScript or Separate?

**QE DOM is accessed through ExtendScript but is technically a separate internal Adobe API layer.**

- QE DOM was "built for internal testing and automation" by Adobe
- It is accessed via ExtendScript by calling `app.enableQE()`
- It is NOT part of the official ExtendScript DOM - it's an undocumented layer
- However, it REQUIRES ExtendScript to access it - there is no other interface

**Source:** [Vakago Tools - Understanding the Adobe Premiere Pro QE API](https://vakago-tools.com/premiere-pro-qe-api/)

---

### 8. Adobe Statements About QE DOM's Future

Bruce Bullis (Adobe):

> "No additional work is planned on the unsupported, undocumented PPro ExtendScript QE DOM."

> "The QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."

> "The QE DOM has some issues updating itself, in response to user interaction."

There are **no statements suggesting QE DOM will be ported to UXP** or receive any updates.

**Sources:**
- [Adobe Community Forums](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-pro-extensions-to-uxp-or-not-to-uxp/td-p/11326933)
- [Adobe Community - Timeline Editing API Request](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115)

---

### 9. Alternative Ways to Access QE Functionality

**Within UXP:**
- Adobe is working toward "1:1 parity" with ExtendScript DOM (not QE DOM)
- UXP can apply effects (previously QE-only)
- UXP can make Undo groupings
- UXP can clone and remove track items

**Still missing in UXP (was in QE):**
- Moving clips between tracks
- Source-target patches control
- Timeline zoom/view control
- Some effect application methods

**Workaround (until Sept 2026):** Run a CEP panel alongside your UXP plugin - CEP can still access QE DOM via ExtendScript.

**Source:** [Adobe Community - Full UXP support ETA](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/full-uxp-support-eta/td-p/15352929)

---

### 10. Bridges or Workarounds to Call QE from UXP

**NO direct bridges exist.**

- UXP does NOT support `evalScript()` to call ExtendScript
- UXP has "1 unified environment" - no ExtendScript bridge
- CEP's `CSInterface.evalScript()` has no UXP equivalent

**Potential workarounds (not officially supported):**
1. **External process communication:** Use websockets or local HTTP server to communicate between a UXP plugin and a separate CEP panel or script runner
2. **Hybrid approach:** Run both a CEP panel (for QE access) and UXP plugin simultaneously
3. **Feature requests:** Request specific QE functionality be added to UXP API

**Sources:**
- [Hyper Brew - Scripts vs Extensions vs Plugins](https://hyperbrew.co/blog/scripts-extensions-plugins/)
- [Adobe Developer - UXP APIs](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/fundamentals/apis/)

---

## Summary Table

| Question | Answer |
|----------|--------|
| `app.enableQE()` in UXP? | NO |
| `qe` global in UXP? | NO |
| Successful UXP + QE examples? | NONE FOUND |
| QE after Sept 2026? | LIKELY NO (dies with ExtendScript) |
| QE part of ExtendScript? | Accessed via ExtendScript, but separate layer |
| QE future updates? | NO updates planned |
| QE porting to UXP? | NO indication |
| Direct UXP-QE bridge? | DOES NOT EXIST |

---

## Key Timelines

- **December 2024:** UXP for Premiere Pro entered public beta
- **November 2025:** Premiere Pro 25.6 released with full UXP support
- **September 2026:** ExtendScript/CEP support planned to end
- **Post-Sept 2026:** QE DOM will likely be inaccessible (no ExtendScript = no QE access)

---

## Recommendations

1. **Do not rely on QE DOM for new UXP plugins** - it is inaccessible
2. **File feature requests** for specific QE functionality you need in UXP
3. **If QE is essential**, continue using CEP until September 2026
4. **Monitor UXP API updates** - Adobe is actively adding functionality
5. **Plan migration** away from QE-dependent features before September 2026

---

## Sources

- [Adobe Developer - Premiere UXP API](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- [Adobe Developer - Premiere and UXP Introduction](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/introduction/)
- [Adobe Community - To UXP or not to UXP](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/premiere-pro-extensions-to-uxp-or-not-to-uxp/td-p/11326933)
- [Adobe Community - Timeline Editing API Request](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115)
- [Adobe Community - Full UXP Support ETA](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-discussions/full-uxp-support-eta/td-p/15352929)
- [Premiere Pro Scripting Guide](https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/)
- [Hyper Brew - Premiere Pro UXP Beta](https://hyperbrew.co/blog/premiere-pro-uxp-beta/)
- [Hyper Brew - Scripts vs Extensions vs Plugins](https://hyperbrew.co/blog/scripts-extensions-plugins/)
- [Vakago Tools - Understanding the Adobe Premiere Pro QE API](https://vakago-tools.com/premiere-pro-qe-api/)
- [GitHub - AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples](https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples)
- [GitHub - Adobe-CEP/Samples PProPanel](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/blob/master/PProPanel/jsx/PPRO/Premiere.jsx)
- [Adobe Tech Blog - UXP Arrives in Premiere](https://blog.developer.adobe.com/en/publish/2025/12/uxp-arrives-in-premiere-a-new-era-for-plugin-development)
